comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
As far as I can tell, "Smith's Wharf" was on the western edge of Millers Point - we are looking south up Darling Harbour.

The wharf was redeveloped shortly after, as in this 1903 photo of the reverse view, then known as Dalgety's Wharf - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4886823914/]

The amazing thing is that John Degotardi Jnr the photographer managed to make a routine photo of a barge clearing rubbish from a wharf into an interesting study in composition, perspectives, light and shapes.  I bet he was also responsible for the photo above and these - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4580719852/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5889052507/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6265044516/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5168027276/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yep, spot on. This map shows the location of Smith's Wharf, the same location as the "new" Dalgety's Wharf opened in 1903 after the Darling Harbour Resumptions - Plan E, Map of Resumption Area bounded by Darling Harbour, Port Jackson, Kent Street North, Windmill Street, and Bettington Street (Within section 92), 03 May 1900.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Eeek! Your link says "Invalid entity path", whatever that means. Try this for Plan E - gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/wp-content/gallery/darling-har... And for all the Resumption Maps - gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/index.php/galleries/maps-and-p...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks, the image page must be displayed on a temporary page. <s>I've changed the link to the permanent item record.</s> Scrub that, it appears you can't link to the record page either. (I was trying to link to Archives Investigator map which is higher resolution than the gallery version.)

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Nice work, from Smith's Wharf to Dalgety's Wharf! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Yes, for some reason we can't link to items in Archives Investigator from Flickr. A very roundabout way is to go to: Archives Investigator --> Advanced Search --> 19348 (in Series Number) then you will see Plan E in the list of Items. AB
